content.main_concept: Cane Use - Proper Technique and Safety Instructions
content.key_points:
**Use of Cane - Proper Technique**

- **A cane should be handled on the stronger side of the body** (unaffected side)
- Hold the cane 6 inches lateral to the base of fifth toe
- The handle is approximately at the level of the greater trochanter
- Handle the cane on the unaffected side (not the affected side)
- When going up the stairs, step up on unaffected then place cane and affected extremity on the step
- **Weight-bearing relief principle**: The cane is in contact with the floor at the same time as the affected extremity

questions.question_text: Which of the following discharge instruction/s on the use of cane is/are appropriate for the nurse to give a client? Select all that apply.
options: 1. Hold the cane 6 inches lateral to the base of the fifth toe.
2. Handle the cane on the affected side.
4. When going up the stairs, step up on the unaffected extremity then place the cane and the affected extremity on the step.
5. Make sure that the handle of the cane is approximately at the level of the greater trochanter.
questions.rationale:
**RATIONALE**

Hold the cane in the hand opposite of the affected extremity (i.e., the cane should be used on the good side) to allow partial weight-bearing relief because the cane is in contact with the floor at the same time as the affected extremity.

extraction_metadata.notes: Complete cane use concept from left page of PDF page 181. SATA question type identified by 'Select all that apply' language and multiple correct answers (1, 3, 4, 5). Includes comprehensive technique guidelines.
extraction_metadata.reference: The Lippincott Manual of Nursing Practice Philippine Edition, Lippincott Williams and Wilkins
